comments:
Ecliplse was working fine for me till yesterday, but following error has popped 
up from today, when i try to run any java application from RUN menu (or 
toolbar), due to which i am not able to run any java application from eclipse.

Please suggest the possible reasons and the solutions to the same.

Error Message:
Exception occurred during launch
Reason:
 Error within Debug UI:

Details of the error in log file are:
!ENTRY org.eclipse.debug.ui 4 120 Apr 23, 2004 13:30:33.771
!MESSAGE Error logged from Debug UI:

It looks like there is a source archive on your source lookup path that is 
contained in a non-java project. This is a bug, but will likely not be fixed 
in the 2.X stream. As a workaround, if you can identify the archive, you 
should be able to move it to a Java project.

Sorry, I misread the code. This looks like an unexpected result from 
IResource.getProject(), which is returning null. What does your source lookup 
path look like (on the source lookup tab)?.

Thank you Darin for your immediate feedback.
We corrected the source lookup path as you had suggested, that it resolved the 
issue.
Now i am able to run any java application from eclipse.
Thank you again for your feedback.
Just wondering however that whether the IResource.getProject() method needs 
updation so that valid data is returned instead of null. Also, the error 
message and exception do not help in understanding the cause.

Do you know what resource was returning null? From the javadoc, it looks like 
only the workspace root should return null for "resource.getProject()", but an 
archive should not be the workspace root.

yes, i had a variable in source lookup path, pointing to a root folder (F:\), 
which was causing the bug. I tried out a couple of examples creating variables 
with path as root folders and the bug was reproduced.

Maybe an extra check when creating a new variable, which forces user to specify 
atleast one subfolder of the root folder, will prevent such issues to happen 
further ahead during development. Of course, i am not sure if such a check 
would introduce any other implications or what.

Cheers anyway,

Thanks - the same problem probably exists in 3.0, so we should add extra 
checks to avoid this.
Fixed in JavaSourceLocator. Please verify, DarinW.
